elements.content: Multicomponent crystallization is universally important in various research fields including materials science as well as biology and geology, and presents new opportunities in crystal engineering. This process includes multiple kinetic and thermodynamic events that compete with each other, wherein “external triggers” often help the system select appropriate pathways for constructing desired structures. Here we report an unprecedented finding that a lattice strain accumulated with the growth of a crystal serves as an “internal trigger” for pathway selection in multicomponent crystallization. We discovered a “spontaneous” crystal transition, where the kinetically preferred layered crystal, initially formed by excluding the pillar component, carries a single dislocation at its geometrical center. This crystal “spontaneously” liberates a core region to relieve the accumulated lattice strain around the dislocation. Consequently, the liberated part becomes dynamic and enables the pillar ligand to invade the crystalline lattice, thereby transforming into a thermodynamically preferred pillared-layer crystal.

elements.content: Biological systems are in a far-from-equilibrium state, where a diverse range of components with various lifespans emerge and interact in different pathways before they disappear. Usually, such multiple biological events proceed, in order, because of the timely selection of appropriate pathways. The concept of pathway complexity is highly important, not only in biology but also in other systems including multicomponent assembly and crystallization, and raises the question of how pathway selection can be executed. In a well-designed biological process, a key component that can internally trigger pathway selection may be produced according to a designated timeline. Although a new strategy to mimic biological pathway selection using in situ produced “internal triggers” has been reported, nonbiological processes have generally been considered to require physical or chemical external triggers for pathway selection. Here we report that lattice strain accumulated with the growth of a crystal serves as an “internal trigger” for pathway selection in multicomponent crystallization. While optimizing the conditions for the three-component synthesis of a pillared-layer crystal (PLCryst) from a mixture of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis­(4′-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin (2HPor), 4,4′-azopyridine (AzoPy), and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, we noticed the selective formation of a layered crystal (LCryst) from the zinc complex of 2HPor (ZnPor) and bridging Zn2+ by excluding AzoPy. After a while, LCryst started to accommodate AzoPy specifically at its geometrical center to undergo crystal transition to accomplish the formation of target PLCryst. Note that a series of events involved in this crystal transition occurred “spontaneously” without the addition of any external trigger. Why and how does this pathway selection spontaneously occur?

Introduction

Biological systems are in a far-from-equilibrium state, where a diverse range of components with various lifespans emerge and interact in different pathways before they disappear. Usually, such multiple biological events proceed, in order, because of the timely selection of appropriate pathways. The concept of pathway complexity is highly important, not only in biology but also in other systems including multicomponent assembly and crystallization, and raises the question of how pathway selection can be executed. In a well-designed biological process, a key component that can internally trigger pathway selection may be produced according to a designated timeline. Although a new strategy to mimic biological pathway selection using in situ produced "internal triggers" has been reported, nonbiological processes have generally been considered to require physical or chemical external triggers for pathway selection. Here we report that lattice strain accumulated with the growth of a crystal serves as an "internal trigger" for pathway selection in multicomponent crystallization. While optimizing the conditions for the three-component synthesis of a pillared-layer crystal (PLCryst) from a mixture of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4'-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (2HPor), 4,4'-azopyridine (AzoPy), and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, we noticed the selective formation of a layered crystal (LCryst) from the zinc complex of 2HPor (ZnPor) and bridging Zn2+ by excluding AzoPy. After a while, LCryst started to accommodate AzoPy specifically at its geometrical center to undergo crystal transition to accomplish the formation of target PLCryst. Note that a series of events involved in this crystal transition occurred "spontaneously" without the addition of any external trigger. Why and how does this pathway selection spontaneously occur?

elements.content: In retrospect to the history of crystallization described below, we assume that a screw dislocation must exist at the geometric center of LCryst, which plays an essential role in such a “spontaneous” crystal transition event. In 1929, Sloat et al. reported spiral markings on the crystal surface of silicon carbide, which was later correlated mechanistically with a screw dislocation, as proposed by Frank based on an experimental evidence given by Griffin suggesting that unimolecular growth steps on a crystal surface afford growth spirals. Together with Burton and Cabrera, Frank established BCF theory in 1951, providing the rationale that screw dislocations facilitate crystal growth by generating successive turns of energetically favored growth steps at a low level of supersaturation or supercooling. In 1953, Eshelby constructed a theoretical model to show that a thin rod with a screw dislocation along its longer axis displays an elastic twist, i.e., the Eshelby twist. Most likely, the Eshelby twist forms spontaneously to relieve the internally accumulated strain around the screw dislocation in 1D crystals. This theoretical model complemented the prediction by Frank in 1951 regarding the influence of an internal lattice strain on the crystallization events. Now, we come back to the question of why and how the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition, highlighted in the present work, spontaneously occurred without the help of any external trigger. Given that the internal lattice strain in the layered crystal of LCryst around the screw dislocation is exponentially enlarged with lateral crystal growth, the liberation of the core part of LCryst likely occurs to relieve the internally accumulated lattice strain. The liberated core part becomes structurally dynamic, thereby allowing initially rejected AzoPy to invade the crystalline lattice and bridge the constituent ZnPor 2D layers to form PLCryst. Although the importance of lattice strain has often been discussed with the formation of screw dislocation and associated growth spirals, its essential role in pathway selection to trigger crystal transition has never been recognized.

elements.content: As described above, our original aim was to synthesize PLCryst from a mixture of 2HPor, AzoPy, and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O. Typically, we heated a mixture of 2HPor (5 mM), AzoPy (10 mM), and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (15 mM) at 65 °C for 24 h in a mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and ethanol (EtOH) at a volume ratio of 3:1 (a and a, see Supporting Information for details), where 2HPor was quantitatively transformed into its zinc complex (ZnPor) (Figure S2a). To optimize the reaction conditions, we monitored the crystallization event by optical microscopy and electronic absorption spectroscopy (see Supporting Information for details), where we noticed the appearance of single-crystalline LCryst (a, Stage I, and b, [i]) rather than PLCryst. The absence of AzoPy in LCryst was supported by 1H NMR spectroscopy of a digested mixture of LCryst with aqueous deuterium chloride (DCl) in deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6) (Figure S2c). Upon continuous heating at 65 °C (a, Stage II), LCryst started to display a square-shaped boundary around its geometric center (b, [ii]), whose inner region was then transformed into PLCryst (a, Stage III), affording a hybrid crystal structure (b, b, [iii], and S6). Then, the residual LCryst part started to disappear, thereby accomplishing the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition (b, [iv]–[vi], and S4). clearly shows the sequence of these elementary steps. As also confirmed by , nearly all of the LCryst crystals followed Pathway 1, whereas a direct pathway (Pathway 2) to PLCryst including AzoPy together with ZnPor and Zn2+ was not selected (a). 1H NMR spectroscopy of a digested mixture of PLCryst in DMSO-d 6/aqueous DCl showed the presence of AzoPy and ZnPor at a 1:1 mol ratio (Figure S2c). We also succeeded in detaching the core PLCryst part from the hybrid crystal structure by carefully applying mechanical shock and confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy that its composition was identical with that of PLCryst finally obtained (e and inset table in Figure S2c).

Results and Discussion

Spontaneous LCryst-to-PLCryst Transition

As described above, our original aim was to synthesize PLCryst from a mixture of 2HPor, AzoPy, and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Typically, we heated a mixture of 2HPor (5 mM), AzoPy (10 mM), and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (15 mM) at 65 °C for 24 h in a mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and ethanol (EtOH) at a volume ratio of 3:1 (a and a, see Supporting Information for details), where 2HPor was quantitatively transformed into its zinc complex (ZnPor) (Figure S2a). To optimize the reaction conditions, we monitored the crystallization event by optical microscopy and electronic absorption spectroscopy (see Supporting Information for details), where we noticed the appearance of single-crystalline LCryst (a, Stage I, and b, [i]) rather than PLCryst. The absence of AzoPy in LCryst was supported by 1H NMR spectroscopy of a digested mixture of LCryst with aqueous deuterium chloride (DCl) in deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6) (Figure S2c). Upon continuous heating at 65 °C (a, Stage II), LCryst started to display a square-shaped boundary around its geometric center (b, [ii]), whose inner region was then transformed into PLCryst (a, Stage III), affording a hybrid crystal structure (b, b, [iii], and S6). Then, the residual LCryst part started to disappear, thereby accomplishing the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition (b, [iv]-[vi], and S4).  clearly shows the sequence of these elementary steps. As also confirmed by , nearly all of the LCryst crystals followed Pathway 1, whereas a direct pathway (Pathway 2) to PLCryst including AzoPy together with ZnPor and Zn2+ was not selected (a). 1H NMR spectroscopy of a digested mixture of PLCryst in DMSO-d 6/aqueous DCl showed the presence of AzoPy and ZnPor at a 1:1 mol ratio (Figure S2c). We also succeeded in detaching the core PLCryst part from the hybrid crystal structure by carefully applying mechanical shock and confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy that its composition was identical with that of PLCryst finally obtained (e and inset table in Figure S2c).

elements.content: (a) Reaction conditions for the stepwise LCryst-to-PLCryst transition. (b) Selected snapshots and (c) polarized optical microscopy (POM) imaging for the “spontaneous” LCryst-to-PLCryst transition at 65 °C. POM images [i] and [vi] represent single-crystalline LCryst and PLCryst, respectively, and [ii]–[v] represent a transient period between two states. White-colored broken curves represent outer edges of the crystalline shell of LCryst, while insets in [ii] and [iii] represent the magnified POM images of their core regions. Single-crystalline LCryst, along its c axis, is optically isotropic and non-birefringent in POM [i]. However, the square-shaped core region, after liberation, becomes birefringent (blue-colored) as a consequence of its structural disordering via dynamic slippage of the ZnPor 2D layers [ii] (see Figure d). The resulting offset geometry allows AzoPy to be incorporated into the ZnPor 2D layers and bridge the zinc paddlewheel units. This dynamic event in the core region gradually proceeds from its periphery to its center, evidently from the corresponding birefringence color change from blue to pink [iii]. Further progress of this LCryst-to-PLCryst transition [iv] and [v] from the thermodynamic structural ripening results in the formation of single-crystalline PLCryst with a pink-colored birefringence [vi].

elements.content: The crystallographic features of LCryst were investigated by grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (c and S5a–S5c), where the in-plane XRD pattern of LCryst deposited onto a Si(100) substrate was correlated with that of a reported porphyrinic metal–organic crystal with a tetragonal geometry. This result indicates that all ZnPor ligands are bridged by the coordination of their carboxylate groups with zinc ions in paddlewheel units (c). The selected-area electron diffraction pattern of LCryst obtained from transmission electron microscopy (TEM) showed a layered structure with a tetragonal geometry (Figure S6d). The out-of-plane XRD pattern for LCryst displayed three distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 6.3°, 12.6°, and 18.9°, which could be indexed as (001), (002), and (003), respectively. Thus, the interlayer distance (d) in LCryst was estimated to be 1.4 nm (Figure S5c). As shown in e, the crystal structure of PLCryst obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis at 100 K showed that the ZnPor ligands, similar to the case of LCryst, are bridged by zinc paddlewheel units and that AzoPy bridges the paddlewheel units in every other ZnPor layer, thereby resulting in the pillared layer three-dimensional structure (Figures S5d and S5e). Viewed along the crystallographic b axis, two identical frameworks are mechanically interlocked with each other in a slipped cofacial manner (e and S5e).

Structural Analysis by X-ray Diffraction

The crystallographic features of LCryst were investigated by grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (c and S5a-S5c), where the in-plane XRD pattern of LCryst deposited onto a Si(100) substrate was correlated with that of a reported porphyrinic metal-organic crystal with a tetragonal geometry. This result indicates that all ZnPor ligands are bridged by the coordination of their carboxylate groups with zinc ions in paddlewheel units (c). The selected-area electron diffraction pattern of LCryst obtained from transmission electron microscopy (TEM) showed a layered structure with a tetragonal geometry (Figure S6d). The out-of-plane XRD pattern for LCryst displayed three distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 6.3°, 12.6°, and 18.9°, which could be indexed as (001), (002), and (003), respectively. Thus, the interlayer distance (d) in LCryst was estimated to be 1.4 nm (Figure S5c). As shown in e, the crystal structure of PLCryst obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis at 100 K showed that the ZnPor ligands, similar to the case of LCryst, are bridged by zinc paddlewheel units and that AzoPy bridges the paddlewheel units in every other ZnPor layer, thereby resulting in the pillared layer three-dimensional structure (Figures S5d and S5e). Viewed along the crystallographic b axis, two identical frameworks are mechanically interlocked with each other in a slipped cofacial manner (e and S5e).

elements.content: Concerning the “spontaneous” LCryst-to-PLCryst transition via the hybrid crystal intermediate, the following two questions arose: what exists at the geometric center of LCryst (question 1) and what triggers the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition (question 2)? To address question 1, we utilized tapping-mode atomic force microscopy (AFM) to characterize the surface of LCryst isolated from Stage I (a) and found a beautiful growth spiral, that developed consecutively from the geometric center of LCryst (a) to its peripheral edge (b), affording a spiral pyramid on the crystal surface (c). This growth spiral had a terrace width of 320 nm and a Burgers vector b modulus of 1.4 nm (d), which is consistent with the interlayer distance of LCryst (Figure S5c). On the basis of the BCF theory, the above observations indicate the presence of a single screw dislocation at the geometric center of the growth spiral. In contrast to the case of 1D crystals, visualization of screw dislocations in layered crystals, including LCryst, is generally impossible, because the layered crystalline shell around the screw dislocation is too thick for TEM imaging. Therefore, we attempted to etch the surfaces of LCryst with trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) in DMF at [TFA] = 0.3 mM (). When the surface etching was briefly carried out over 5 s, LCryst did not show any change detectable by optical microscopy (g, [i] → [ii]). However, when the surface etching was carried out for 90 s, LCryst became thinner than it was before etching (g, [iii], and S5) and had a tiny through-hole at the geometric center (g, [iv]). We analyzed the surface features of the resulting acid-etched LCryst by tapping-mode AFM and found that the 5-s etched LCryst (g, [ii]) already had a tiny pit (h and i) at its geometric center, while the other regions mostly maintained a growth spiral pattern. These observations support our prediction that LCryst carries a single screw dislocation at the geometric center of its growth spiral. Furthermore, in a rare case, we observed a pair of growth spirals with opposite helical handednesses on one side of a single crystal of LCryst (e and f). In such cases, they grew competitively to form polycrystalline PLCryst ().

elements.content: Then, what triggers the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition (question 2)? On the basis of the previously proposed dislocation models, the crystal lattice around the screw dislocation most likely accumulates more strain as LCryst grows laterally (j and see Supporting Information for details). When the accumulated lattice strain reaches the upper threshold, above which LCryst cannot survive, LCryst needs to relieve such internally accumulated strain to prevent the lattice breakdown of the entire crystal. Thus, LCryst spontaneously breaks off and liberates its highly strained core region (j). Then, this liberated part becomes structurally dynamic. Here, the most likely event that may happen to this liberated LCryst piece is the slippage of the ZnPor 2D layers (d). Density functional tight-binding (DFTB) calculations suggested that slippage of the ZnPor 2D layers is more energetically favorable than interlayer expansion (Figure S8 and see Supporting Information for details). The resulting offset geometry of the ZnPor 2D layers allows AzoPy to diffuse into the liberated LCryst piece and bridge every other layer through coordination with the zinc paddlewheel structures, affording mechanically interlocked PLCryst as a thermodynamically preferred product (e). Because we consider that this dynamic event, followed by the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition, would cause stepwise deterioration of the single-crystalline feature of LCryst into a polycrystalline feature, we employed polarized optical microscopy (POM), which could sensitively visualize how such a deterioration event proceeds in LCryst (c and S9). As typically seen in c, [i], LCryst is optically isotropic when viewed along the c axis and invisible under cross-polarized conditions. In contrast, PLCryst is optically anisotropic when viewed along the c axis and birefringent with a pink color (c, [vi]). The interior of the square-shaped boundary, which appeared in the core region of LCryst in an initial stage of its crystal transition, was barely birefringent similar to its parent LCryst (c, [i]). However, this part gradually became birefringent, exhibiting a characteristic blue color from its periphery to the interior (c, [ii]), which spontaneously transitioned into a pink color (c, [iii]). These observations are indicative of the polycrystalline nature of the square-shaped core region, which is favorable for the diffusion of AzoPy to accomplish the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition. After complete detachment from the residual layered crystalline part (c, [iv]–[vi]), the liberated piece eventually matured as single-crystalline PLCryst with the characteristic monochromatic pink-color birefringence (c, [vi]). The sequence of these optical events in POM imaging is consistent with our proposed mechanism for why and how the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition “spontaneously” occurred. In relation to the subsequent growth of liberated PLCryst, we confirmed that, in the presence of a mixture of ZnPor, AzoPy, and Zn2+, small crystals of PLCryst, separately prepared, grew larger without forming LCryst (). Namely, PLCryst, once formed from the strained core part of LCryst, templates its own crystal growth.

After complete detachment from the residual layered crystalline part (c, [iv]-[vi]), the liberated piece eventually matured as single-crystalline PLCryst with the characteristic monochromatic pink-color birefringence (c, [vi]). The sequence of these optical events in POM imaging is consistent with our proposed mechanism for why and how the LCryst-to-PLCryst transition "spontaneously" occurred. In relation to the subsequent growth of liberated PLCryst, we confirmed that, in the presence of a mixture of ZnPor, AzoPy, and Zn2+, small crystals of PLCryst, separately prepared, grew larger without forming LCryst (). Namely, PLCryst, once formed from the strained core part of LCryst, templates its own crystal growth.

Conclusions

In the present work, we serendipitously found that an internally accumulated lattice strain enables pathway selection in multicomponent crystallization. As shown in , two out of three components were initially selected to form a structurally simple (kinetically preferred) 2D crystal with a screw dislocation at its geometric center, which spontaneously underwent a crystal-to-crystal transition to form a structurally complicated (thermodynamically preferred) 3D crystal by inviting the initially excluded component. Most intriguing was the fact that this spontaneous crystal transition was triggered by a lattice strain in the 2D crystal, which was accumulated around the dislocation along the crystal growth. Screw dislocation and an associated issue of lattice strain have been one of the central interests in modern crystal science and engineering. However, the role of accumulated lattice strain in crystal transition (pathway selection) has not been recognized so far, because its visualization requires continuous observation of the crystallization event as well as a suitable combination of components that can elongate the lifetime of the initially formed crystal. This finding may lead to a new strategy for the precision design of functional multicomponent crystals with core-shell architectures.

cln_elements.content: The crystallographic features of LCryst were investigated by grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (c and S5a–S5c), where the in-plane XRD pattern of LCryst deposited onto a Si(100) substrate was correlated with that of a reported porphyrinic metal–organic crystal with a tetragonal geometry. This result indicates that all ZnPor ligands are bridged by the coordination of their carboxylate groups with zinc ions in paddlewheel units (c). The selected-area electron diffraction pattern of LCryst obtained from transmission electron microscopy (TEM) showed a layered structure with a tetragonal geometry (Figure S6d). The out-of-plane XRD pattern for LCryst displayed three distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 6.3°, 12.6°, and 18.9°, which could be indexed as (001), (002), and (003), respectively. Thus, the interlayer distance (d) in LCryst was estimated to be 1.4 nm (Figure S5c). As shown in e, the crystal structure of PLCryst obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis at 100 K showed that the ZnPor ligands, similar to the case of LCryst, are bridged by zinc paddlewheel units and that AzoPy bridges the paddlewheel units in every other ZnPor layer, thereby resulting in the pillared layer three-dimensional structure (Figures S5d and S5e). Viewed along the crystallographic b axis, two identical frameworks are mechanically interlocked with each other in a slipped cofacial manner (e and S5e).

cln_elements.content: (a) Reaction conditions for the stepwise LCryst-to-PLCryst transition. (b) Selected snapshots and (c) polarized optical microscopy (POM) imaging for the “spontaneous” LCryst-to-PLCryst transition at 65 °C. POM images [i] and [vi] represent single-crystalline LCryst and PLCryst, respectively, and [ii]–[v] represent a transient period between two states. White-colored broken curves represent outer edges of the crystalline shell of LCryst, while insets in [ii] and [iii] represent the magnified POM images of their core regions. Single-crystalline LCryst, along its c axis, is optically isotropic and non-birefringent in POM [i]. However, the square-shaped core region, after liberation, becomes birefringent (blue-colored) as a consequence of its structural disordering via dynamic slippage of the ZnPor 2D layers [ii] (see Figure d). The resulting offset geometry allows AzoPy to be incorporated into the ZnPor 2D layers and bridge the zinc paddlewheel units. This dynamic event in the core region gradually proceeds from its periphery to its center, evidently from the corresponding birefringence color change from blue to pink [iii]. Further progress of this LCryst-to-PLCryst transition [iv] and [v] from the thermodynamic structural ripening results in the formation of single-crystalline PLCryst with a pink-colored birefringence [vi].
